title-group.article-title: Seemingly Empty: Freud at Berggasse 19, A Conceptual Museum in Vienna

abstract.p: In this article, the author posits and argues for a new category of museums: the conceptual museum. By taking the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna and its Contemporary Art Collection as a case study, she suggests that museums that are seemingly empty, for instance, without objects, are, in fact, filled with their own histories, contingencies and epistemological confluences, which, when they come into contact with the personal histories, fantasies, knowledge, expectations and longings of their visitors produce a rather full encounter.

disp-quote.p: Now let us, by a flight of imagination, suppose that Rome is not a human habitation but a psychical entity with a similarly long and copious past – an entity, that is to say, in which nothing that has once come into existence will have passed away and all the earlier phases of development continue to exist alongside the latest one.
Space may be the projection of the extension of the psychical apparatus. No other derivation is probable.

There is no replacement, no reconstruction; one just realizes that there are empty rooms [in the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna], and one has to find one’s way through them. There is no memorializing, rather, the experience is always different, and is concerned with challenging and playing with the viewer’s expectations. The challenge of the last 25 years has been to communicate through space (rather than objects) and ask questions of space, its histories, etc.

In 1975, the time of my first visit [to the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna], it was an apartment with bare walls, no furniture, and a few glass cases with manuscripts and other minor memorabilia. It was dominated visually by [Edmund Engelman’s 1938] photographs, blown up to life size, of how it once had been, photographs that stood in for all the objects that had been removed to London when the Freuds escaped from the Nazis. It had a derisible atmosphere, perhaps one deliberately induced to remind visitors of yet one more loss that the war had visited on Vienna; but it still prompted the thought that a museum of fake souvenirs is a fake museum – a screen museum, the Freudian might say.

body.p: ‘I remember that I was both excited and afraid as I walked through the empty streets [of Vienna] toward Berggasse 19 that wet May morning in 1938’ (Engelman, 1998[1976]: 89; see also Werner, 2002). And so begins the young photographer Edmund Engelman’s memoir, recounting his journey to visit the aging and ailing Freud at the behest of the psychoanalyst’s close friend and colleague August Aichhorn. The surreptitious, and highly dangerous visit was undertaken in order to photograph and record Freud’s professional and personal living quarters at Berggasse 19: spaces that the psychoanalyst had occupied for the previous 47 years; and to do so immediately as the Freud family were in the midst of the complex coordination of their flight from Nazi Vienna to a life of freedom and exile in London.

On 4 June 1938, the Freud family fled Vienna with all of their possessions in tow, leaving their apartments in Berggasse 19 empty. After a short stay in Paris, the Freuds made their way to London, and within a few months they settled into their new home at 20 Maresfield Gardens. Here the family unpacked their belongings, including the psychoanalyst’s famous couch with its Persian rug laid over it, his peculiar anthropomorphic chair, his desk, ashtrays, writing implements, his enormous collection of over 2,000 antiquities and the remainder of his book collection, as well as the family’s private furnishings. As visitors to the Freud Museum at Maresfield Gardens London know, here we are able to view and experience these objects in their then new, and now permanent surroundings.

Engelman shot 106 photographs of Berggasse 19, Vienna (Werner, 2002: 447).2 Enlargements of the photographs he took of Freud’s consulting room and study – the spaces that form the core of psychoanalytic practice and its theorization – together with a collection of archival material, form the basis of the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna. Otherwise, the Museum is almost entirely empty. As Lydia Marinelli, the late Director of Research at the Museum, and the editor Georg Traska succinctly put it: the Freud Museum Vienna is ‘a site stripped of its material core’ (Marinelli and Traska, 2002: np). This stripping highlights, embodies and echoes the Freud family’s departure; a pervasive impression of absence; and an irreducible rupture in history.

The Museum’s emptiness and the profound sense of absence it affects on its visitors have been negatively remarked upon since it opened. One of these commentators is the historian and philosopher of psychoanalysis and the human sciences John Forrester. As quoted in the epigraph above, Forrester’s first visit to the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna produced in him, as he remembers it, a rather harsh and negative reaction. The ‘derision’ with which he recalls the Museum was based on the fact that it was a great disappointment. ‘With bare walls, no furniture, and a few glass cases with manuscripts and other minor memorabilia’, and dominated by Engelman’s photographs, the Freud Museum in Vienna held within it a host of ‘fake souvenirs’. It was, and it has been argued that it remains, devoid of any real, proper objects. It is filled with nothing, and thus ostensibly empty. For Forrester it is a ‘fake museum’, which, he suggests, Freudians may refer to as a ‘screen museum’. Forrester is not alone in his assessment of the Museum; many other visitors throughout its history have shared this type of reaction.

I will return to consider Forrester’s and some of the other comments made about the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna quite closely but, for now, I would like to pose a few questions in order to frame my discussion in this article. What exactly is it that Forrester and others, including myself, see and experience when visiting the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna? What is it that we wish or desire to see and experience? And, what, in the end, do we not see, but do experience? As I propose and argue in this text, at Berggasse 19 we have so much that is present, but not in the traditional way in which a museum functions. In the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna, and other museums that are founded upon empty spaces, something different occurs. Rather than a museum’s objects and collections driving our visit, a museum of empty spaces institutes a radical difference in what a museum is, how it functions, and our experience of it. That is, the empty spaces – their histories, representations, memories, and our experiences of these spaces – come together to form what I would like to name a ‘conceptual museum’.

The Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna is just such a conceptual museum. In this analysis, I consider the history of the Freud family’s living and work spaces and the documentation of these spaces as a vital, living archive. I see the negative critiques of the seemingly empty Museum and what they offer us in terms of our understanding of a museum of radical difference. The Freud Museum’s small, yet permanent ‘site-responsive’ conceptual Contemporary Art Collection will be my guideline. This will lead to the suggestion that the Museum can be understood to be modeled on Conceptual Art. This, then, will shape the way in which together these aspects of the Freud Museum in Vienna foster a notion of a conceptual museum.3 Through this accumulation of argument and analysis I posit that a conceptual museum more generally, and the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna specifically, are based upon a complex interweaving of the historical, theoretical and imaginative potentialities of a site, and their affect on the viewer.

sec.title: A Living Archive In the Making
sec.p: Freud and his family were forced to leave Vienna after the German Anschluss of Austria by Hitler’s Third Reich on 12 March 1938 had a very real impact on them.4 On 15 March, the Gestapo searched Freud’s home. On 22 March, the Nazis detained Freud’s youngest daughter Anna for interrogation. ‘In her bag, she hid a capsule with a lethal dose of Veronal that she had received from Dr Schur, the family physician’, so that, if necessary, she could choose to take her own life. After an entire day of being held and ‘several hours of interrogation, Anna Freud was released’ (Scholz-Strasser, 1998: 8; see also, Schur, 1972). On that day, 22 March 1938, Freud, anxious for the safety of his daughter and taking heed of the spread of anti-Semitism across Europe made a decision. Although, as Freud wrote to his friend and colleague Arnold Zweig, he was still in a frail condition and recuperating, on ‘the couch which is meant for others’ in ‘unusually violent pain’, from one of his ‘normal operations’ for the mouth cancer that he had been battling for 15 years, Freud knew, without a doubt, that emigration was a necessary measure for the survival of his family (Freud in Scholz-Strasser, 1998: 8).

In this hostile climate, the Jewish photographer Engelman understood what was at stake in his visit to the Freuds less than two months later. Engelman continues his memoir by stating that:
I carried a little valise filled with my cameras, tripod, lenses, and film and it seemed to become heavier and heavier with every step. I was convinced that anyone who saw me would instantly know that I was on my way to the offices of Dr. Sigmund Freud – on a mission that would hardly have pleased the Nazis.
It had only recently stopped raining. The sky was still dark and the cobblestones of Berggasse were glossy and wet. The dark day worried me. I was afraid that there might not be enough light for good interior photographs of the Freud apartment. Flash and floodlights were out of the question. I had been told that the apartment was under constant surveillance by the Gestapo. The only permanent record of the place where Freud had lived and worked for the last forty years would have to be made without arousing any suspicion whatsoever. I felt fear for my own safety and also for the Freuds, for I did not want to be responsible for some misstep which would endanger them now that they were so close to leaving Vienna safely. (Engelman, 1998[1976]: 89)

Having met with Freud’s friend and colleague Aichhorn at the Café Museum on Karlsplatz a few days earlier, Engelman agreed that, as
the historic apartment and offices were about to be broken up for storage and shipment … it would be of utmost importance for the history of psychoanalysis … to make an exact record of every detail of the place where it was born so that, in Aichhorn’s courageous words, ‘a museum can be created when the storm of the years is over’. (p. 93)

Thus, for posterity and the projection of a Freud Museum in the future, Engelman spent four days taking photographs of Berggasse 19. As we can see from Engelman’s photograph (Figure 1), he took shots of the building’s exterior, including the street, the building’s façade with all the windows of the Freud family’s residence, Kornmehl’s kosher butcher shop, and the cooperative food hall that was a branch of a Social Democratic Consumers’ Union both on the ground floor, as well as the imposing front door to the building (which as Engelman notes, ‘on this day was draped with a swastika flag; another large swastika flag hung from the roof of the building’ (p. 95). Once inside, Engelman photographed the spacious entrance and hallway, the glorious 19th-century stone staircase, and the exterior doors to apartments 5 and 6 (Freud’s living and professional quarters, respectively). Stepping inside Freud’s apartments, Engelman shot detailed photographs of their interiors.5 Engelman’s mission was to photograph the spaces of Freud’s personal life and professional practice, including his study, consulting room and his patients’ waiting room while always ‘keeping in mind that some day these photographs might be the only record available to recreate Freud’s offices and living quarters’ (p. 96).

caption.p: Façade of Berggasse 19, Vienna, 1938. Photograph: Edmund Engelman.

sec.p: The photographer, using two cameras (a Rolleiflex and a Leica), two lenses (a 150mm lens and a 28mm wide-angle lens) and a light meter, wanted to record as much as possible ‘from positions where Freud usually stood or sat … to see things the way Freud saw them, with his own eyes, during the long hours of his treatment sessions and as he sat writing’ (p. 96). However, in practice, this presented technical difficulties and Engelman conceded to taking photographs from different vantage points, including those of the patient or visitor.

Most of Engelman’s photographs are of what he called the ‘important rooms’ – the study and consulting room – that he rushed to enter, unwittingly having taken only a couple of photographs of the waiting room (p. 96). Upon entering the consulting room, his ‘first glance’ of ‘the famous couch’ left him somewhat disappointed, as it struck him as ‘relatively small’; but he was ‘overwhelmed’ by the ‘masses of figurines which overflowed every surface’ and ‘filled every available spot in the room’ (p. 97).6 He photographed the consulting room in detail. An example of this close attention to detail can be seen in the photograph (Figure 2) which includes the couch and its surround, the many pictures and pieces of art in the room, the typical Viennese ceramic tile stove, and the cabinets holding some of Freud’s vast collection of antiquities. In other photographs, Engelman shot the chair Freud sat in during his patient’s analysis, and the mementos and awards hanging on the room’s walls. Engelman visited the Freuds over only a few days, which afforded him very little time to photograph the study. In one of these shots (Figure 3) we can see a part of Freud’s extensive library and antiquities collection; his desk with its army of antique figurines which faced him while he read and wrote; the ‘quite strange’ chair that was designed especially for Freud; and the ‘oddly decorative mirror’ that hung from the large windows in his study. The view from the windows looked out onto a courtyard (p. 98). Engelman made notes as he worked across the consulting room and study: his archival gaze documenting the spaces and their contents was meant to ensure that nothing was missed and that the photographs overlapped one another, thereby creating a detailed and complete panorama of the rooms.7 And yet, as the literary theorists Diana Fuss with Joel Sanders (2004: 78) note, at times, Engelman’s working methods became ‘slightly manic’ as he ‘obsessively transvers[ed] the same spaces’ and found it difficult to ‘negotiate the crowded terrain of Freud’s office, so cluttered with objects that many of the two thousand antiquities can be seen in these photographs spilling onto the study floor’.8

caption.p: Freud’s Consulting Room, Berggasse 19, Vienna, 1938. Photograph: Edmund Engelman. Image: Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna.
Freud’s Study, Berggasse 19, Vienna, 1938. Photograph: Edmund Engelman. Image: Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna.

sec.p: During one of these visits, while Engelman was at work, Freud unexpectedly interrupted him by walking into his study. Surprised by the meeting, as Engelman was told explicitly that he would not be meeting Freud who was not well enough to receive guests, the two men were introduced by Aichhorn who explained the photographer’s visit to the psychoanalyst. Upon meeting and liking Engelman, Freud agreed to have his portrait taken by him, as did his wife Martha and daughter Anna. Engelman was welcomed to photograph the family’s living quarters, which were furnished in traditional upper middle-class Austrian design, with hardwood furniture, Oriental rugs, decorative crystal and China objects, family photographs and other memorabilia. Engleman also gained access to, and photographed Anna Freud’s consulting room and sitting room, which she used for her professional psychoanalytic work with children. Each day as the photographs were shot, Engelman spent the entire evening and much of the night developing his pictures. The photographer organized and collated all of the images into an album, which, upon completion, Engelman presented to Freud.

Engelman understood that, as a Jew, he too needed to escape Nazi Vienna. He knew that the negatives could not travel with him in case they were found by the Nazis on his person, and threatened his life and the lives of the Freud family. As such, he left the negatives with Aichhorn in Vienna. After many months of hope, despair and hardship, Engelman managed to leave Vienna in January 1939, spent some time in a French detention camp, and finally made his way to New York in early 1940. Many years later, Engelman followed the trail back looking for the negatives. He found out that they had been sent by Aichhorn’s secretary Miss Regele to Anna Freud in London for safe keeping. Engelman visited Anna Freud at Maresfield Gardens and collected the negatives.

sec.title: From 1891 to 1938: A Brief History of Berggasse 19
sec.p:
Freud and his family had moved into the newly built apartment 5, Berggasse 19 Vienna, in 1891.9 Berggasse 19 was built as a part of a major process of city planning during the mid-19th century:
The decision to raze the city’s fortifications in 1857 and replace them with a magnificent avenue encircling the inner city, the Ringstrasse, as well as the building activity throughout the city that accompanied those economic and political boom years of successful bourgeois industrialists and entrepreneurs, the so-called Gründerzeit, transformed the appearance of Vienna and determined to a great extent how the city looks today. The monumental buildings along the Ringstrasse were an architectural manifestation of the relationship between conservative-imperial and liberal-bourgeois modes of self-perception. The domestic architecture of the municipal districts adjoining the ‘Ring,’ numbered as they were at the time in Roman numerals II. to IX., was characterised by a specific type of multiple-story, bourgeois apartment building. (Scholz-Strasser, 1998: 15)

The Freuds moved into one of these typical buildings in a ‘socially diverse’ part of the city that represented a mixture of the noble, secular, ecclesiastical, Jewish, economic and intellectual life of Vienna (p. 16).

A few years after taking up residence in Berggasse 19, Freud began to see his patients there. His practice migrated into the ground floor apartment 4 in Berggasse in 1896, and then, in 1908, when his sister Rosa Graf and her family vacated apartment 6 – the flat adjoining the Freud family quarters – Freud moved his practice into it. In 1923, Anna Freud began her practice as a child therapist in apartment 5, the family’s private quarters, and her patients shared the waiting room with her father’s analysands in apartment 6. For over 15 years, with a great deal of praise from her father and the psychoanalytic community, Anna Freud also carried out her work and writing at Berggasse 19.

Freud lived and worked at Berggasse 19 for 47 years. As we know from Engelman’s photographs, as well as through correspondence and various texts written by friends, colleagues and patients, the psychoanalyst surrounded himself in his study and consulting room with his sizeable and treasured collection of antiquities and artifacts, and a substantive library. Freud was able to engage with these objects and books while sitting in the comfort of his unique anthropomorphic chair (a gift in 1930 from his daughter Mathilde, designed by Paul Hofmann, and made by the architect and family friend Felix Augenfeld), pacing within these spaces, or lying on his analysands’ couch (a gift in 1891, apparently from his grateful patient Mrs Benvenisti). At Berggasse, Freud saw nearly all of his patients; wrote the bulk of the major works of psychoanalysis; carried out a lengthy correspondence with colleagues and friends; hosted the Wednesday Psychological Society (which became the Vienna Psychoanalytic Society in 1910) that met at Berggasse from 1902–1922 (until the waiting room became too small to hold all of its members); worked with his students; welcomed guests; and raised a family.

Having lived a full and productive life here, Freud, at the age of 82, along with his wife Martha, sister-in-law Minna Bernays, and his daughter Anna had no choice but to leave Vienna. In order to pay the heavy taxes levied by the Nazis on Jews hoping to leave occupied territory, the Freud family had to sell a large portion of the psychoanalyst’s book collection, borrow funds from family and friends – particularly the author and psychoanalyst Princess Marie Bonaparte –and, with the assistance of the American and British Governments, were finally granted permission by the Nazis to leave Vienna on 4 June 1938. Astonishingly, they were able to take with them almost all of their belongings, and these are what we can still view today in the Freud Museum London.

With the Freuds’ departure from Berggasse 19, the Nazis at first used their apartments as a form of ‘communal housing’ for Jews. In 1941 or 1942, the occupants were transferred to an official Jewish ghetto in the 2nd district of Vienna. Here they were detained until they were deported to concentration camps. Freud’s four sisters, all over 80 years old, were victims of this process, eventually being murdered in the concentration camps (Scholz-Strasser, 1998: 21).

In extreme contrast to this, the Nazis then used these ‘vacated’ Jewish apartments to house non-Jewish Viennese families. As Hertha Pfeiffer (quoted in Scholz-Strasser, 1998: 21) told a journalist in 1989:
We got the apartment number 5 on Berggasse 19 in 1942, the Freud apartment … My God, the apartment was available … The apartment was available. Completely empty. There was absolutely nobody in it. That’s the way it was then. It was so simple. There was no problem. …
In 1942, the Nazis appropriated apartment number 6 and declared it to be a Reichsmietwohnung z.b.V., a ‘vacant’ apartment especially designated for relatives of soldiers serving in the German Wehrmacht. The apartment was subdivided in the same year. The Henkel family moved into the former rooms of Sigmund Freud’s practice, and the Stoff family moved into Anna’s.

After the War, Vienna made very little effort to acknowledge Freud’s life, exile, and legacy. It was not until 1953 that a plaque was attached to Berggasse 19. It simply states: ‘From 1891 to 1938, in this house, lived and worked Professor Sigmund Freud, creator and founder of Psychoanalysis.’

sec.title: An Archival Museum
sec.p: Then, in 1968, with the founding of the Sigmund Freud Society in Vienna, Frederick J Hacker, its first President, received grants from the federal government and the Vienna city council to begin the process of acquiring apartment 6 – the central spaces of Freud’s professional practice between 1908 and 1938, including the hallway and coat rack, the waiting room, consulting room and study – in order to establish a museum. (Apartment 5, Freud’s family home, was not acquired by the Museum until 1986.) Under the purview of Dr Harald Leupold-Löwenthal, who later became President of the Sigmund Freud Society, the rooms of apartment 6 were quickly renovated in order for the Museum’s opening to coincide with the 27th International Psychoanalytic Congress in 1971 in Vienna. This was the first Congress to take place in Vienna since the rise of National Socialism. These spaces formed, and remain to this day, the core of the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna. In 1971, almost 35 years after Freud was forced to leave Vienna, the empty spaces of Berggasse 19, once alive with the private lives, and the intellectual and professional labour of Freud, his family, colleagues and friends, became a Museum dedicated to Freud. On 15 June 1971, the Freud Museum opened to the public. Anna Freud, having been kept abreast of the Museum’s development returned to Vienna for the first time since the Freuds fled Austria, to celebrate this occasion: a Museum in Vienna dedicated to her father’s life and work.

Before the Museum’s launch many design options were discussed by the committee, headed by Leupold-Löwenthal, which was in charge of its design, organization and display. The committee conferred upon, but decided against an extreme conceptual arrangement. One possibility was to have a replica couch and a single armchair placed in their original positions during Freud’s time, within an otherwise empty consulting room (Marinelli and Traska, 2002: np). Instead of this type of a radically empty, conceptual installation for the Museum (i.e. having only an armchair and a replica couch occupying the entire space which was once inhabited by Freud’s study, consulting room and waiting room), ‘the basic idea of [the Museum’s] design’ was ‘to present the 1938 appearance of the rooms by means of enlargements of Engelman’s photographs and, in addition, to give a pictorial presentation of Sigmund Freud’s life and development and of his creation, psychoanalysis’ (Leupold-Löwenthal, 1994/1995: 7). This is the design the committee duly employed for apartment 6.

During the Museum’s planning stages, Anna Freud was contacted and as a part of her contribution to the Museum she sent from London the furniture that once inhabited the waiting room in Berggasse, so that that space would to a certain extent resemble the layout during her father’s lifetime. Anna Freud also donated a small selection of Freud’s antiquities, several volumes from his book collection, and various other documents to the newly formed Museum.

Because the bulk of Freud’s collection of antiquities, books, and furniture remained at Maresfield Gardens, where Anna Freud was still living and practising, the Museum staff in Vienna decided to produce a rather ‘didactic’ (Marinelli and Traska, 2002: np) display of Freud’s consulting room and study through various types of archival documentation: photographs by Engelman and others; diagrams; first editions and off-prints of Freud’s work leant by various institutions and private collectors; hand-written inscriptions; souvenirs; as well as other archival material.10 For the first decade of the Museum’s life, a total of 140 photographs and original documents were placed in the consulting room only, which is a great deal of material for a rather small room. In 1974, further material was added (Scholz-Strasser, 1994/1995: 9). The archive and documentation on display in this core part of the Museum – the waiting room, consulting room, and study - now total 351 pieces. This is quite an archive, and quite an extensive exhibition of material. Intriguingly, the majority of the archive is displayed around the edges of the consulting room and study, and housed within flat, built-in wall cabinets. Engelman’s enlarged photographs are displayed on the bottom half of the cabinets, forming a flat, panoramic screen-like display of how the vibrant and brimming rooms once were. Thus, the two-dimensional display emphasizes both what is absent – all of the objects, artifacts, books, furniture, that were once held within the two rooms - and the emptiness of the rooms themselves. It is this sense of emptiness that provokes such confusion, hostility, anger, and disappointment in the Museum’s visitors. It is also one of the most intriguing and meaningful aspects of the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna. I will return to this again later.

For now, I would like to simply introduce a context for this type of radically conceptual installation in relation to Conceptual Art exhibitions. In order to do this, I will bring to mind both the radical possibility that the Freud Museum committee entertained – of having only a replica couch and chair in the consulting room – and the display that the Museum ended up with, which produces a concerted sense of emptiness. Both of these spatial arrangements echo, and in fact contribute to, the long history of the radical empty gallery space as employed by artists, mainly conceptual artists, as a means of pointing to and denoting the constitution of the gallery and the artwork as an ideological, social, economic and cultural construction. This genealogy begins with Yves Klein’s The Specialization of Sensibility in the Raw Material State Into Stabilized Pictorial Sensibility, otherwise known as Le Vide/The Void (Paris: Galerie Iris Clert, 1958). It has a crescendo in the late 1960s and early 1970s at the height of Conceptual Art with installations by Art & Language, Robert Barry, Robert Irwin and Michael Asher; and then moves intermittently from the early 1990s with shows by Laurie Parsons and Bethan Huws to the early 2000s with exhibitions by Maria Eichhorn, Ilya and Emilia Kabakov, through to the recent work by Roman Ondák.11 Clearly the opening of the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna in 1971 occurs in the middle of this history, and notably coincides with the focal point of the empty gallery exhibition at the height of Conceptual Art. This coincidence draws our attention to the wider reverberations induced by the Freud Museum: the relationship between the Museum and Conceptual Art’s exhibition history; the Vienna Museum’s conceptual Contemporary Art Collection; the radically conceptual emptiness of the Museum and the criticisms it provokes; and the historical, cultural and ideological context for the Museum.

The opening of the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna in 1971, and the creation of this seemingly empty museum with its paradoxical excess of archival documentation require further reflection. Leupold-Löwenthal (1994/1995: 7) thought that the visitor required some support in garnering a sense of what was once in these spaces, and the proliferation of archival documentation on display. For this purpose, he and Hans Lobner produced,
with the simplest apparatus … the first mimeographed catalogue, which was needed because it was our policy to avoid having captions under the pictures, so as not to disturb the graphic representation and the arrangement of the photographs and documents.

To this day, visitors are presented with the option of using one of these catalogues – now photocopied and translated into several languages – to assist them as they make their way through the Museum. The catalogue gives detailed information of each of the 351 items on display. This abundance of archival material and documentation resonates with the ways in which, at its height, Conceptual Art also had a similar reliance on this type of material.

The visitor to the Freud Museum cannot possibly read the 100-page booklet of documentation that he or she is given upon arrival at the museum, or consider it in its entirety while visiting and viewing the 351-item strong archive on display. There is simply not enough time to read through the documentation, and thus I suspect that very few visitors use it in any extensive or exhaustive manner. This means that visitors are left to view the archive on display in a rather cursory fashion, glancing from one item to the next, until their gaze lands upon something that is of particular interest. This item is then looked up in the catalogue and read about in detail. This sense of vagueness about what one is looking at and sees must certainly add to the sense of absence and emptiness that visitors experience in the space.

As each item on display is numbered and referenced in the catalogue, this programmatic structure within the display determines to a large extent how the visitor moves in and around Freud’s professional work spaces. After walking across the entrance hallway and through the analysands’ waiting room, the visitor, like the analysand, is guided into the consulting room. The display and catalogue strictly orient the visitor in the consulting room and study (see Figures 4 and 5): immediately upon entering the consulting room, the viewer’s gaze is shifted to the left; the first item in the catalogue is described. He or she is then guided around the edge of this space, until reaching the doorway to the study. As in Freud’s time, these double doors are always open. Thus they emphasize the correlation between practice and theory, between listening and writing. Having moved halfway around the consulting room, Museum guests are then invited into the study and led around it in a counter-clockwise rotation. Eventually they arrive at the small mirror that hangs at the centre of the large windows in the study, so that the visitors, like Freud before them, can gaze upon their own image. From here, visitors return to the double doors and move back into the consulting room, to complete the viewing of this room’s other two walls, and then back out to the waiting room. This counter-clockwise movement through the consulting room and study establishes their integral connection to one another, a connection that was of vital importance to Freud.12 What is striking about this path is that the visitor is made to walk around the edge of the exhibition space, rather than across, or through it, thereby emphasizing once more and physically experiencing its overall emptiness and strong sense of absence. This also makes clear that there is a radical difference between this museum and a traditional museum filled with objects in vitrines situated within its exhibition space rather than around its edge.13 Together, the archival, documentary, and anthropological approach taken in the Freud Museum’s display – the flattened, two-dimensional layout creating a screen-like display; the use of souvenirs, the prevalent use of photography; the didactic nature of the catalogue; and the way in which visitors are guided around the space – come together to emphasize a seeming emptiness, and thus make apparent what is seemingly absent in the Museum.14
