Freud’s study, Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna. Photograph: Florian Lierzer. © Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna.

sec.p: Seemingly empty, seemingly absent. And I will return to this ‘seemingly’ later. For now, I would like to emphasize that, as my analysis has made clear so far, the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna functions, on one level, as an archival museum. Many of the most important of Engelman’s 106 images have been on display since the Museum’s opening as they are to this day. As a whole, they still constitute a vital photo-documentary archive with and through which we can ostensibly recreate, imagine, and understand what was present in the site where psychoanalysis’s beginnings, histories, genealogies and its ruptures took place: Berggasse 19. These photographs embody a sense of the aura of Freud’s consulting room and study; the spaces of life and labour within which the practice and writings of psychoanalysis became manifest. In thinking through the abundance of documentation and archival material though, the image-screen created by Engelman’s photographs, the relatively few pieces of furniture in the waiting room, and the substantive catalogue detailing each item on display and its importance to Freud’s life and work, it becomes clear that the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna display in apartment 6 is extraordinary. There are very few objects to be viewed; however, there is a great deal of documentation to be seen and a proliferation of notes to be read. And, yet, in spite of this proliferation, the consulting room and study remain seemingly and strikingly empty; the overriding sense of the Museum is that it is paradoxically full of absence.

This paradox, a Museum that is both overflowing and yet empty, reminds us, as Ingrid Scholz-Strasser, the Director of the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna, insists, as quoted in the epigraph at the beginning of this article, that any endeavour to retrieve and represent the past, to ‘replace’ or ‘reconstruct’ it, is impossible. What this means in light of my analysis, is that the aura of these spaces during Freud’s lifetime is irrecoverable, the historical rupture is irreducible, and the images thus function as a loss through and with which we live. It is this absence and paradox that produces such negative reactions in visitors, and, which also provides them with some rather disturbing fantasies.

sec.title: This Is Not a Museum
sec.p:
Lydia Marinelli, affiliated with the Freud Museum since 1992, and the Director of the Research Division at the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna from 2004 until her untimely death in 2008, cogently writes about the complicated responses that visitors and museum experts have had and, one can conjecture, continue to have towards the Museum. She remembers attending a course for museum professionals. During this event, the functions and conditions of what constituted a museum were being discussed, and one participant spoke up and said, ‘I don’t think you [the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna] deserve the name. You shouldn’t call yourselves a museum, what you have here has nothing to do with a museum. Museums exhibit works of art or collections, but this…’ Although the instructor attempted to explain the ways in which the definition of the museum had been opened up, and the possibilities it could now serve had shifted, it seemed that even the most liberal and open-minded of the participants had difficulty in accepting the Freud Museum as a museum. Marinelli (2009: 161) explains that:
the reservations expressed concerned the Sigmund Freud Museum in Vienna, which had been branded the product of name usurpation … It was not a matter of revising the definition of ‘museum’ or of less outmoded objectives for the institution. What was being expressed here was the inadequacy of this place itself, the incongruity between the notion and the location, the idea and the social institution, which initially eluded conceptual systematization. This sense of incongruity is caused by the fact that this museum does not offer to the eye what the associations surrounding the institution demand; instead of satisfying visitors’ expectations, it disappoints them.

Disappointment and frustration are responses that the Museum has provoked for some time. In the 1960s, the French psychoanalyst Jacques Lacan visited Berggasse 19, and ‘found to his disappointment nothing but a shabby and locked door. What had he hoped to see but a house, plain and simple?’ (p. 163). Other visitors bring such longing and desire with them that they imagine seeing what is not there: the couch, for instance. Marinelli mentions how visitors coming back to Vienna to visit the Museum once more, insist that during their last visit Freud’s couch was in Vienna: which of course it was not, since it has not been in Vienna since Freud’s exile in 1938. Berggasse 19, and Freud’s life are so many things to so many visitors.

disp-quote.p: For some it is an everyday residence where they have led their day-to-day lives since the end of the Second World War; others confront this life with traumatic memories in which this mundane, everyday life was founded on violence; still others believe that a center of the psychoanalytic world lay buried here. (p. 164)

sec.p: The radical difference of the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna means that all of these interpretations and desires of what will be found at Berggasse are thwarted. It simply does not function in the way that traditional ‘personality museums’ based on the life and work of a famous person (most often a man) do.15 Traditionally, the visitor expects to see ‘the remains of an authentic-looking interior, preferably one that creates the impression that the poet, philosopher, etc. has just left the room’. This creates ‘a continuum between past and present through a suggestive interplay of absence and presence. Things of the past do not seem lost in this context, but rather aufgehoben in both senses of the Hegelian term, i.e. both preserved and raised to a higher level (p. 164). This is certainly what the Freud Museum in London accomplishes. It is a memorial and mausoleum to Freud. This is precisely what the Freud Museum in Vienna cannot fulfil. In Vienna, ‘normality, banishment, genocide, and psychoanalytic myths of origin commingle’ and these ‘stories converge that in other narratives move apart’ (p. 163).

This convergence of narratives, and its irreducibility, must be maintained within the Freud Museum Vienna in order for it to reverberate with its own history. The core of the Museum must remain
an empty place, an empty apartment, which has nothing but an address to mark it and serves as a permanent reminder of obliteration and banishment, the room resists the affirmative construction of meaning and remains inherent as a block in traumatic constellations. The story that can be told about it creates no safe horizon that could lend itself to stabilization. In fact, the exhibited emptiness is not merely the product of history, but is equally the product of a form-giving intervention – as are other undertakings working in three dimensions also. The museum answers the question of what there is to see here by highlighting the moment of disappearance and becoming the signpost to a place located elsewhere. (pp. 165–166)

What Marnielli points to, and enables me to argue is the way in which the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna puts the issue of representability itself into question. Here, it is not a matter of representing trauma, but the impossibility of doing so that is embodied, enacted and affected by the Museum. This Museum is not a trauma museum. Rather it is a site of trauma.16 The Freud Museum Vienna does not function as a form of memorialization, as positive reassurance as Marinelli rightly states.17 Rather, it maintains the displacement and irreducibility of history, memory and meaning. In these ways, the Museum’s seeming emptiness functions and resonates in such a way as to point to a radical difference from other trauma museums. These radical differences form the basis for an alternative understanding of what a museum can be and does by enabling me to conceive of a conceptual museum.

Here, in Vienna there is no ‘stabilization’, ‘no safe horizon’. It is, as Marinelli (pp. 165–166) puts it, a ‘signpost to a place located elsewhere’. Having said that, what I think it is vital to remember in this Freud Museum, is that this elsewhere is actually located here, in and at the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna. It is here, that the lieux de mémoire, as Pierre Nora (1989: 9) would say, is located; where ‘memory takes root in the concrete, in spaces, gestures, images, and objects’. It is, as Freud notes about Rome in the first epigraph to this article:
a psychical entity with a similarly long and copious past – an entity, that is to say, in which nothing that has once come into existence will have passed away and all the earlier phases of development continue to exist alongside the latest one. (2001[1929/1930]: 70)

As I continue to argue in this text, the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna, as a site of radical difference, as a site of memory is an historical, material, theoretical and affective exemplar of a conceptual museum.

sec.title: Conceptual Art Inside the Museum
sec.p:
The archival, documentary and photographic aspect of the Vienna Freud Museum’s display, as well as Forrester’s summation of it as a ‘screen museum’, are briefly commented upon by the art historian Mignon Nixon in her article on Conceptual Art and psychoanalysis. Nixon (2005: 72) writes:
It is important to observe that certain of the strategies informing the installation of the Freud Museum are also characteristic of Conceptual art. These include the displacement of the object by the photograph and the text and the concomitant frustration of scopic desire, as well as the reorientation of the museum or gallery from an exhibition space, or space of display, to an archive. The Freud Museum, with its ‘derisible atmosphere,’ its photographic record of the rooms in Freud’s time, its research library, its carefully labelled and indexed ‘minor memorabilia’ – and, ultimately, its art collection curated by Kosuth – is a screen museum on the Conceptual art model.18

In these three sentences, Nixon makes a series of important analogies: between the strategies of Conceptual Art, the Vienna Museum’s display, screen memories and the Museum’s Contemporary Art Collection. In an earlier section of this article, I analysed the archival, documentary, anthropological and screen-like aspects of the Museum’s core display. And it is certainly the case that some of these traits are concomitant with Conceptual Art. Perhaps, though, the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna is more closely aligned with the history and criticality of the radically empty exhibition, and its radical difference as a conceptual museum. In this section, I would like to consider more fully the Freud Museum’s Conceptual Art Collection and the unique role it plays within the Museum, as a conceptual museum.

In order to achieve this, I would like to begin by turning to the history of the extraordinary transformations that the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna underwent between 1984 and 2003 under the current Director Inge Scholz-Strasser. These include significant changes to the Museum’s architectural design; the acquisition of estates; the funding, organization and ownership of the Museum; its philosophical, conceptual and epistemological remit; and, last but not least, its relationship to contemporary art. The highlights of these changes are as follows.

In 1984, under Leupold-Löwenthal, the display in Freud’s study and consulting room was rearranged. In 1986, the Sigmund Freud Society, through proceeds from a musical charity event and government funding acquired apartment 5 of Berggasse 19 for the Vienna Museum. This apartment was the Freud family’s private residence between 1891 and 1938, and included Anna Freud’s consulting room from 1923 until 1938. On 23 September 1989, apartment 5 opened to the public. Beginning in January 1991, the apartment underwent an extensive ‘conceptual reconstruction’, in the form of structural renovations initiated by Scholz-Strasser and managed by the conceptual architect Wolfgang Tschapeller.19 In 1992, the Museum set up the Anna Freud Rooms, which include home videos of the Freud family; and the original waiting room shared by Freud and his daughter was modified in 1993. By 1996, the alterations were complete and the Museum now houses spacious offices for the staff; the largest library of psychoanalysis in Europe, with over 35,000 volumes; an archive of over 50,000 objects; and several impressive exhibition spaces for both historical shows and the exhibiting of the Museum’s Contemporary Art Collection.20 In addition to these extensive renovations and changes, in 2002, the Museum opened the then recently acquired entire ground floor of Berggasse 19. What was the cooperative food hall during Freud’s lifetime is now a lecture theatre and seminar room for the Museum’s ongoing research and education programme, and the space adjacent to it, which housed Siegmund Kornmehl’s kosher butcher shop, has become a unique glass-fronted, street-level exhibition space informally referred to as the Storefront Gallery.21 Many of these transformations to the Museum are clearly punctuated by a very real relationship to contemporary art. There are three main moments in this history that I would like to focus on: the first in 1989; the second in 1997; and the final one beginning in 2002.

In 1989, on the occasion of the 50th anniversary of Freud’s death, and the centenary of the Austrian philosopher Ludwig Wittgenstein’s birth, Vienna planned a series of celebratory events. One of these was an invitation extended by the Freud Museum’s Director Scholz-Strasser and the Viennese curator and gallerist Peter Pakesch to the American conceptual artist Joseph Kosuth.22 Scholz-Strasser and Pakesch invited Kosuth to create an artwork that would mark the occasion of these significant historical milestones, and to coincide with the Museum’s opening to the public of apartment 5 at Berggasse 19. Being the first contemporary artist to exhibit at the Museum, Kosuth took the opportunity to make a work that was decidedly responsive to the site. As I mentioned earlier, the Pfeiffer family had inhabited apartment 5 since 1942 after they had been granted the right to move into it under the auspices of the Austrian government’s relocation scheme, and after the Freuds had been forced to leave Vienna. In 1989, when Kosuth was invited to exhibit in the site, the Museum had not yet renovated the apartment. Clearly this was an important moment in the Museum’s history; as well as marking Vienna and Austria’s acknowledgement of Freud and his legacies, it highlighted the relationship between Conceptual Art and psychoanalysis, and Kosuth wanted to ensure that all of this was suitably recognized and made manifest.

In the mid-1980s, Kosuth was working on, amongst other things, his serial installation entitled Zero & Not. The form and content of this work was indebted to Freud’s writings. Kosuth’s project began in 1985 and grew out of his 1981 work Cathexis in which he first posited the notion of a ‘conceptual architecture’, which involves an artwork’s activation of the space, history and memory of its architectural context.23 In each of the works in this series, Kosuth takes an excerpt from Freud’s writings and has the text silkscreened on paper and then applied as wallpaper onto the interior walls of the site. Each paragraph of the text is numbered, and the text is struck through by black masking tape so that the words remain barely legible. Having been given the opportunity to exhibit in the Freud family’s apartment, it seemed only appropriate to construct a piece from the Zero & Not series for the space. For the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna installation Kosuth used an excerpt from the original, German version of Freud’s important, and in the psychoanalyst’s mind his best work, The Interpretation of Dreams (see Figure 6).

caption.p: Joseph Kosuth, Zero & Not (1989), with George Herold, Amour Psyche (1989), Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna, 1989. Photograph © Margherita Spiluttini.

sec.p: Kosuth (1993[1986]: 221–222) states that in the Zero & Not series there is an ‘absence presented’ which precipitates a manifold deconstructive play. For the art historian Charles Green (2001: 20), the particularity of Kosuth’s method highlights the fact that Freud’s ‘text alternate[s] as figure and ground, it also work[s] as discourse itself’. For me, this alternation, and the discursive implications of it bring to mind the terms of Jacques Derrida, wherein the Freud text is put under erasure; struck out, made seemingly absent, and yet is still present in its trace. Because the text is both legible and illegible, this artwork offers us an interpretation of how language and meaning are reliant on the flow of words and their relationship to one another. This is what Kosuth (1993[1986]) calls the ‘texture of reading’. In addition, for the artist, by using only Freud’s words as the basis for his own work and yet putting them under erasure, the work interrogates the notion of artistic as well as psychoanalytic authorship and authority.

The version of Zero & Not made and housed in the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna also reminds us of many other psychoanalytic lessons. The text under erasure, with its lasting trace encourages us to think about Freud’s insights into the functioning of memory, repression and screen memories, wherein experiences leave an ever-present trace of themselves even when they are linked to another experience, barely remembered, or not remembered at all. The textual erasure also brings to mind Freud’s understanding of the human subject as archaeological. For him, our formation is stratified and covered over in various ways. It is the function of psychoanalysis to excavate these layers in order to bring our memories to the fore and offer us self-knowledge and relief from our symptoms. And finally and quite literally, having an excerpt from Freud’s The Interpretation of Dreams reminds us of the psychoanalyst’s groundbreaking work on this subject, especially his use of condensation, displacement and translation, which are quoted in Kosuth’s installation, as pivotal modes of understanding dreams. Interestingly, with regards to the Vienna Freud Museum and my analysis of it, the Zero & Not artwork also brings to the fore the hauntedness of the site, by evoking and activating the spatial configuration, history and memory of the architectural context, what Kosuth calls the artwork’s ‘conceptual architecture’. The text as an imprint of language on the walls of Berggasse reminds us of the importance of language for psychoanalysis, it is after all the talking cure. As well as echoing the multitude of voices indebted to it that spoke to Freud as his patients, colleagues, friends and visitors. Together, these interpretations of Kosuth’s artwork and the lessons it offers us, function intriguingly as a type of screen memory – layering memories and contingent histories (as well as text) – and thus echo the core installation of the Freud Museum itself. From this analysis, it is clear then, that Kosuth’s Freud Museum installation responds and activates the site in numerous ways.

The initiative to show contemporary art in the Freud Museum in 1989 did not stop with Kosuth’s Zero & Not intervention. The artist, working together with Scholz-Strasser and Pakesch, came to invest the Freud Museum, and Vienna, with a vital link to Conceptual Art in another significant way. They decided to procure a contemporary art collection for the Museum, and asked six of the most important conceptual artists of the time to donate one work each to what they initially called the Foundation for the Arts, Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna. Along with Kosuth’s Zero & Not and his work (O.&A./F!D! (TO I.K. and G.F.) (1987), the Foundation acquired John Baldessari’s Study for a Red Intruder (Blue) (1989), Pier Paolo Calzolari’s Avido (1968), George Herold’s Amor and Psyche (1989), a piece from Jenny Holzer’s The Living Series (1981–1982), Ilya Kabakov’s The Man Who Flew into His Picture (1987–1989) and Franz West’s Liège (1989). Thus, in 1989, what had originally been scheduled as a one-person show of Kosuth’s work in apartment 5, ended up being a group exhibition wherein all of the eight artworks were installed in the Freud Museum, and became its first contemporary art intervention. Kosuth’s Zero & Not placed on these walls, imbued as they are with layers of history and memory, became the intellectual and conceptual wallpaper – literally and metaphorically – for the exhibition: the piece and the site function as the context and ground against which all of the other works were displayed.

Within and in relation to Kosuth’s Zero & Not intervention, each of the other artworks found a place in apartment 5: the entrance hall, Freud’s bedroom, Anna Freud’s therapeutic quarters and Freud’s sister-in-law Minna Bernays’ sitting room and bedroom are all inhabited by a work of art. Each work responds to the site and animates the space and its histories in its own way. As Jan Avgikos (1990: 88) points out, there is what he calls an ‘intimation of connection’ here between works and context such that:
Kosuth’s (O.&A./F!D! (TO I.K. and G.F.), taken from Freud’s text on ‘Condensation and Displacement in the Dream-work’ belongs to Freud’s bedroom, installed on the spot where he slept, and dreamed. Verging on hallucinatory representation, in Minna Bernays’ bedroom (its only access through Freud’s own Schalfzimmer), Calzolari’s blue neon Avido (eagerness, greed) mounted above salt-crusted bar and low-slung leather belt is an optative apparatus … we know that all histories, in the retelling, are fictions. Who better than Kabakov to demonstrate. In the large outer sitting room, a free-standing banister demarcating zones signified by text and canvas, he orchestrates a game of transference. In the entrance hall, Baldessari waits to be announced.

The artworks engage with psychoanalysis in various ways. For instance, Herold uses humour to play with the ideas of sex, gender and lust; and several other pieces evoke specific aspects and concepts from psychoanalysis – desire and wit for Calzolari, the uncanny for Baldessari. The functions of dreamwork are clearly referred to in Kosuth’s (O.&A./F!D! (TO I.K. and G.F.). Here, an excerpt from Freud’s work on dreams, condensation and displacement is represented on a panel with a mirror in front of it prompting us to simultaneously read the text, think about dreams, perhaps our own, and view our reflection (see Figure 7). In addition to these, Franz West’s installation Liège, named after a noun which refers to both the German word for a divan-like couch and the town in Belgium, is made up of three items: an iron couch, a pedestal on which it sits, and a document that invites the viewer to lie down on the couch. Together, these secure the installation’s meanings as a work of art, as a participatory and social object, and its dual relationship to psychoanalysis wherein, physically, the analysand lies down during their session, and the way in which the theoretical work of psychoanalysis comes from this therapeutic practice. Kabakov’s installation The Man Who Flew into His Picture brings together a painting made up of an expanse of white background and a tiny, silver figure flying into or perhaps out of the picture frame (see Figure 8). For this work, Kabakov reuses objects found in the Freud apartment when the Museum purchased it: a wooden table, two chairs and a trestle. On the table are a series of notebooks recounting fictitious stories based on the artist’s life and memories of Soviet Russia. The furniture and painting are situated in positions that encourage the viewer to sit down and read through the notebooks. Strongly evoking the site, as well as the notion of memory, what Scholz-Strasser (2010) calls the ‘objects and memory of the site’, this work animates and punctuates Freud’s life, work and exile in provocative and yet subtle ways.

caption.p: Joseph Kosuth, Zero & Not (1989), with Franz West, Liège (1989), Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna, 1989. Photograph © Margherita Spiluttini.
Joseph Kosuth, Zero & Not (1989), with Ilya Kabakov, The Man Who Flew into His Picture (1987-89). Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna, 1989. Photograph © Margherita Spiluttini.

sec.p: At the end of the 1989 show, the seven works of art, excluding Kosuth’s Zero & Not, went on loan to the Museum Moderner Kunst in Palais Liechtenstein for five years and, following the temporary closure of this Museum, the works were sent back to the Freud Museum (Scholz-Strasser, 2006: 4). Kosuth’s Zero & Not installation remained a permanent feature of the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna until 1995 when, due to the extensive renovations of the site, it was taken down. Kosuth visited the Museum and carefully dislodged the wallpaper, turning parts of it into 60 smaller works entitled Schachtel Fragment Zero & Not (1996); 40 of these pieces were given as gifts to members of the Society of Friends of the Sigmund Freud Museum, donors and persons who had made major contributions to the Museum.

The second phase of the Freud Museum’s Contemporary Art Collection’s history occurred in 1997. At that time, the Foundation, still under Kosuth’s directorship, and always in discussion with Scholz-Strasser and Pakesch, expanded to include seven additional new works: Clegg and Guttmann’s Text in Context (1997); Jessica Diamond’s Tributes to Kusama: Me Constellation (1995); Marc Goethals’ Le Nom-du-Pere (1996); Sherrie Levine’s A Pair of Shoes (1974); Haim Steinbach’s AHA! (1997) (Figure 9); and Heimo Zobernig’s Untitled (1997).24 Clegg and Guttmann’s photograph depicts a life-size view of one of the bookshelves in the library at the New School of Social Research in New York, which holds the complete 24 volumes of Freud’s writings, nestled in between other texts related to the psychoanalyst’s thoughts, thereby clearly evoking Freud’s ideas and genealogy. Another artwork which functions in a similar fashion is Zobernig’s silver-sparkled silkscreen print which represents an enlargement of the memorial plaque at the Belle Vue House on the outskirts of Vienna, wherein Freud is said to have discovered the secret of dreams. Goethals’ Le Nom-du-Père (Figure 10) plays with the notion of the phallus and paternal authority, and is heavily indebted to Jacques Lacan’s rewriting of Freud’s work. While Diamond and Levine’s contributions evoke memories of earlier times in one’s life; and the witty work by Steinbach entitled AHA! speaks to that strikingly revelatory and dawning moment in a psychoanalysis when something becomes clear.

caption.p: Haim Steinbach, AHA! (1997), Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna, Foundation for the Arts, 1997. Photograph © Margherita Spiluttini.
Marc Goethals, Le Nom-du-Pere (1996), Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna, Foundation for the Arts, 1997. Photograph © Margherita Spiluttini.

sec.p:
It was at this time in the Museum’s history that the Foundation changed its name and the collection became known as the Contemporary Art Collection, Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna. All of the earlier works along with these later donations were exhibited between November 1997 and January 1998; and then again recently between October 2009 and July 2010.25 In addition to these major exhibitions of the entire Collection, the works are also always making a ‘physical intervention’ into the Museum (Scholz-Strasser, 2010): shown in varying arrangements throughout the Museum’s exhibition rooms and, since 2008, one work from this Collection is always on display in the Storefront Gallery. As Kosuth (1998: 13) succinctly states about the Collection,
I thought it would be valuable to put together an art collection in which post-Freudian thought would actually be manifested internally in the work, rather than simply illustrate the person or times of Freud. To honor this man, the philosophical depth and meaningful role of art in society must be made visible and understood as a valuable part of our cultural experience. The artists invited to join our foundation, as diverse as they are, have an agreed understanding of art’s serious intent, even when humor is its vehicle. The art of this foundation is not simply in the world to decorate, it is here because it has something important to say. As the foundation grows, and its collection, The Sigmund Freud Museum will offer Vienna and the world an ongoing record of the work of succeeding generations of international artists acknowledging the imprint of Sigmund Freud’s life on that cultural horizon which forms our consciousness. It is a monument to Sigmund Freud, and it is a living one.

With this constellation of work in the Contemporary Art Collection and its continued display in the Museum, it is clear that, as the Museum Director Scholz-Strasser notes, ‘a link between psychoanalysis and art [is] established at Berggasse 19’ (2006: 4).

The third and final significant moment to date in the coordination and intervention of contemporary art into the Freud Museum began in 2002 with a series of temporary exhibitions in the Storefront Gallery. Entitled A View From Outside, the series has included nine installations of site-responsive and site-specific works. The series is coordinated and curated by Scholz-Strasser and Pakesch in cooperation with the Society of Friends of the Fine Arts. The artists are given ‘free rein’ to work within the space and site, what Scholz-Strasser (2010) calls the Museum’s ‘laboratorium’, as they see fit.26

These interventions are not a part of the Contemporary Art Collection. As I have mentioned, they are commissioned for the Storefront Gallery and exhibited in what was during Freud’s lifetime Siegmund Kornmehl’s kosher butcher shop. And yet, they have a very particular relationship to the Collection and the Museum. As Scholz-Strasser (2009: 31) notes:
In 2001, within the framework of the museum’s expansion, the integration of the street-level space created a new external surface through which it can communicate with a wider public. The ‘display window’ gave a new definition to the building’s entrance by providing a platform for artistic intervention. Since then, temporary installations on the museum’s ‘outer skin’ have been drawing attention to the Sigmund Freud Museum Contemporary Art Collection.

The Storefront Gallery thus provides an exterior, outside, public space within which contemporary art can be viewed at the Museum. When it is not being used for these temporary exhibitions, the space is employed to exhibit one work from the permanent Contemporary Art Collection.

The architectural and aesthetic make-up of the ‘display window’ Storefront Gallery is that of a glass-fronted white cube space. Standing outside the space, the viewer is able to look inside. It is not possible to walk into and enter the space in order to be next to or view a work of art more closely. This makes for a very peculiar and specific type of viewing practice and scopic regime where we are invited to look into the gallery, rather than be in the gallery. It also highlights two important differences in relation to the viewing practices of the Contemporary Art Collection within apartment 5, wherein we have the opportunity of being and inhabiting, momentarily, the spaces of Freud’s private life and Anna Freud’s professional practice, while circulating in and around the artworks.

In relation to history, as with Freud’s apartments, the space of the Storefront Gallery has a vital, although once more, a different connection to it. In the butcher shop space we are offered a site that connects directly to, for instance, Freud’s everyday life, as well as the lives of another Jewish family, the Kornmehl’s (see Figure 11) who were also forced into exile in 1938 by the Nazi regime. Within this context, the interventions exhibited in the Storefront Gallery, like the artworks displayed in Freud’s apartment, have an immediate relationship to various social, cultural, personal and political histories, as well as the ideas and genealogies of psychoanalysis.

caption.p: Joseph Kosuth, A View to Memory, Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna, 2002. Photograph © Gerald Zugmann/www.zugmann.com

sec.p:
Kosuth’s intervention, A View to Memory (1 May 2002 – Autumn 2003) reflects this connection with these histories in a very clear and direct manner. The artist has taken one of Engelman’s photographs of the occupied, open and active butcher shop from May 1938, and enlarged a fragment of it to fit the inside of the ‘display window’ of the Storefront Gallery; thereby bringing history to life, while keeping it behind doors. The entire photograph is duplicated, framed and hangs to the side of the gallery. Placed at the top of the storefront is an excerpt, in German, from Freud’s Psychopathology of Everyday Life. The text reads:
It is universally acknowledged that where the origin of a people's traditions and legendary history are concerned, a motive of this kind, whose aim is to wipe from memory whatever is distressing to national feeling, must be taken into consideration. Closer investigation would perhaps reveal a complete analogy between the ways in which the traditions of a people and the childhood memories of the individual come to be formed. SE (http://www.freud-museum.at/e/inhalt/museumausstellungenKosuth.htm)
Fitting images and text: they respond, activate and resonate precisely with various lived and traumatic histories embodied in this site.

Again, by employing Engelman’s photographs, this time those of Freud’s consulting room and study, the artist Lala Rascic in A Load From the Inside – Reviewed (22 June – 2 October 2011) engages with the history of the site, and everyday life, this time through Freud’s ideas on memory, forgetting and mistakes. By making a humorous video in which the artist has inserted herself walking, running, sitting, lying down, slipping, sliding and skipping within Engelman’s photographs, Rascic brings to life Freud’s consulting room and study. The mise-en-scène of psychoanalysis becomes the site of a mystery, clues, and its detection. As Jasna Jakšić (2011) has said of Rascic’s installation:
The key question is not ‘who did it’, but rather ‘where are the slips’ hidden in the formal or narrative weave and in which places does reality radiate through? The mechanisms of confusion, misreading, oblivion and faulty memories are significant in the construction of elliptical narrative structures. Along many examples from his own analytical practice and from the experiences of people close to him, Freud also mentions several examples of slips in literature in his ‘Psychopathology of Everyday Life’, placing these slips at the same level with the narratives of ‘real life’.

Another artwork that deals with the histories of Berggasse 19 is Clegg and Guttmann’s complex installation Sha’at’nez or The Displacement Annex (19th March – 19th September 2004, Figure 12). This intervention weaves together Freud’s exile and displacement, psychoanalytical ideas and books on displacement, and the Biblical Hebrew term sha’at’nez from Leviticus 19:19, meaning a combination of things that are foreign to one another, and thus displaced. The installation is of a usable library and desk, open to guests. It brings together for the first time since 1938 volumes of books (originals, facsimiles and dummy books) on the topic of displacement that had been a part of Freud’s library at Berggasse. Clegg and Guttmann’s assemblage also reproduces parts of the libraries where these books are now kept: Freud’s study at Berggasse; the new library in the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna; the study at the Freud Museum London; the library and collection at the Psychiatric Institute of New York City which bought books from an antiquarian bookseller known to have purchased volumes directly from the Freuds in 1938. The installation is ‘a hybrid, leaning tower of books, temporarily reuniting his dispersed collection’ (Scheyerer, 2005; see also Clegg and Guttman, 2004). This annex to Freud’s libraries, past and present, is represented in an installation where knowledge sits seemingly unsteadily, yet securely in place. Through a series of displacements, and absent presences, various histories are brought together in a displaced site: Kornmehl’s butcher shop, now the Storefront Gallery.

caption.p: Clegg and Guttmann, Sha’at’nez or The Displacement Annex, Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna, 2004. Photograph © Gerald Zugmann/www.zugmann.com

sec.p:
Kosuth, Rascic and Clegg and Guttmann’s interventions clearly evoke, respond and activate the site of Berggasse 19. As Scholz-Strasser (2009: 32) states about the A View From Outside series more generally:
The installations confronted passersby, museum visitors and art lovers with a variety of artistic approaches to the site Berggasse 19, and with artistic interpretations of key concepts in the work of Sigmund Freud, such as repression, displacement, condensation, dream and trauma.

So, yes, it is true as Nixon intimates, and as I have shown, the Freud Museum’s core display functions in similar ways to Conceptual Art. But it is also clear that the Museum’s relationship to contemporary art does much more than iterate these alliances. Like the earlier pieces acquired in 1989, the 1997 donations to the Museum, and the A View From Outside series function as site-responsive artworks, enlivening the Museum in specific ways, while also being animated by the particularity of the site’s historical, theoretical and phenomenological context. What is especially important to remember is that the exhibition spaces in the Freud Museum are spaces that are inhabited by history and memory, haunted by them, and not by objects. And unlike white cube spaces in the modern art gallery, wherein there is a presumed and supposed erasure of history and memory, a notion that the Conceptual Art exhibitions I discussed earlier critique, the Freud Museum, even with its white walls, still retains its histories and memories.27 In this space, the Contemporary Art Collection – its presence and display – and the A View From Outside series enable certain types of practices to take place: Conceptual Art; thinking art; referential art; an art of displacement, of analogy; an art of classification, of archives, and, to a certain extent of objects; and most certainly an art of meaning and of interpretation. Thereby they make an important and subtle connection to Freud’s interest in art, which was not concerned with aesthetics but with meaning and interpretation (see Forrester, 1997; also Bettelheim, 1989a[1956]).

sec.title: A Conceptual Museum
sec.p: For Forrester, as I have noted, the memory of his visit to the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna included a ‘derisible’ atmosphere; made up as it was of ‘fake souvenirs’ within a ‘fake museum’. This reference to ‘fakeness’ evokes the analogy he goes on to make between the Museum and Freud’s notion of screen memories. Simply put, a screen memory is when a memory is screened over by another memory. So, in the case of the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna, Freud’s life and career in Berggasse is screened over by the ‘fake souvenirs’; by the photographs and the rather scant, almost negligible collection of objects which come to stand in for Freud’s couch, chair, his extraordinary collection of antiquities and impressive library. But is this necessarily the case? In bringing this article to a close, I would like to take a closer look at Freud’s theory of screen memory and the way in which visitors, including Forrester and Lacan, have reacted to the Freud Museum. In so doing, I continue to argue that what we have here is not a screen museum as much as a conceptual museum.

For Freud, screen memories are a function of memory based on distortion, displacement, substitution, forgetting and remembering. Freud posits that in screen memories a child has an important experience that is essentially to do with thwarted desire; it is repressed and seemingly forgotten. This process leaves a distorted trace of the experience as a mnemic image. This mnemic image is screened over by a manifest congruent, earlier, or later, and often unimportant experience and its mnemic image trace. The screening over takes place through contiguity, displacement (metonymically), substitution (metaphorically), or translation. The screen memory becomes manifest, substituting the important experience and memory. Sometimes the memory is ‘falsified’, but, as Freud makes clear, ‘these falsifications of memory are tendentious’ (Freud, 2001[1899]: 322). The mnemic image becomes entangled and remains so, until it is, as Freud puts it, ‘formed’ by being remembered, uncovered, unknotted, revised, reinvented, redescribed, narrated and understood later in life, often during a patient’s psychoanalysis. Thus at the centre of screen memories and the mnemic image is desire: forbidden, thwarted, repressed and forgotten. We would do well here to bring to mind Adam Phillips’ (1994) work on forgetting:
Forgetting in its versions of disguise, makes desire accessible by making it tolerable. We can only desire because we can hide things from ourselves. The defences, as described by Freud are a repertoire of forms of forgetting … psychoanalysis is a cure by means of the kind of remembering that makes forgetting possible. (pp. 24–25)

This is a rather complex formulation, and becomes more complicated in light of the Freud Museum. To begin, we can now understand why, for many, visiting the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna is disappointing and frustrating. The image-archive constitutes the Museum’s main display, and evokes an ‘archaeology of the image’ as screen image and mnemic image: what I have called a screen-like display. As we see clearly in Freud’s analysis of screen memories, the image is key to understanding the formation and function of memory, as well as to understanding psychoanalysis as a theory and practice (Pollock, 2006).28 The image-archive on display in the Vienna Museum and the few objects in the waiting room are supposed to function contiguously, metonymically, synecdochally, or through translation as substitutions for our desires. Fulfilling, at least momentarily, our earlier thwarted, repressed and forgotten desires. But, they do not and cannot fulfil our expectations and desires. Why?

The photographs for Forrester are fake souvenirs, and perhaps this is the case, but they are also a form of documentation, a type of screen image, a memory trace of what once was and, in this way, they function as a form of remembering. Whether it be the history of Freud’s life and work, or the trauma of his exile, or displacement more generally, they are a reminder of what is missing, of what has been seemingly forgotten, repressed and hidden from memory. Again, there is this ‘seemingly’ to think and work through. To a certain extent our frustration, anger, resentment, confusion and the fantasies that confront us in the Freud Museum Vienna are the function of what Freud calls the ‘working-through’ of psychoanalysis: the remembering, uncovering, acting out, resisting and repeating that takes place through a long period of time, through the transference in a psychoanalysis that leads to our understanding and overcoming of our histories (Freud, 2001[1914]: 145–156). Freud never suggested that working-through was pleasurable.

Moreover, we bring so much to the Museum. We bring our expectations, desires, understanding, longing, fantasies and forgotten memories and their relations to Freud. They relate to his life and exile; to the objects we know or want, or falsely remember even, to be in the Museum and on the site; to psychoanalysis as a history, theory, practice; to our selves as human subjects; to what our expectations are as tourists and visitors to a site of historical significance, and to what a museum should be. We come to the Freud Museum with these and other desires, expectations, longings, fantasies, memories. Whether mundane, serendipitous, highly significant, conscious or unconscious, we do not come to the Museum empty-handed. When we enter the Museum and are confronted by its absences, our desires are seemingly screened off and thwarted: we are frustrated and disappointed as we encounter seemingly empty spaces.

But it is vital to remember that we have not arrived empty-handed. Although there is seemingly nothing to see, I would like to suggest that, with our desires and fantasies in hand, there is too much to see, and too much to remember in these spaces. Too much that is ‘of desire’, as Freud would say. And this makes personal, historical and collective forgetting impossible. Our resistances are down as our memories and desires rise to the surface, emerge and reemerge in these spaces; we remember too much, and are able to forget too little.

These memories and desires are set alight and brought to life by what is present at Berggasse 19: by what we are unable to forget. By the fact that there is a great deal that is present. The building’s architecture, including its façade, and famous 19th-century stone staircase. On the ground floor we find the first consulting room and study in the apartment which is now used as one of the Museum’s offices, as well as Kornmehl’s butcher shop and the cooperative store. Upstairs, in apartment 6, we enter Freud’s inner sanctum, the joint consulting room and study, filled with 330 documents that line their walls representing Freud’s life and work. Adjoining them is the waiting room with its pieces of furniture, antiquities, books and documents donated by Anna Freud in 1971. Anna Freud’s work space includes the family’s home movies playing on a continuous loop. And finally, we encounter the Freud family’s private residence that is now an expansive exhibition space. These spaces constitute a complex historical, imaginative and theoretical site that reverberates and is haunted by the history of the lives of those who lived there – Freud and his family – and by the lives of its visitors – the family’s friends and relatives, as well as Freud and his daughter’s colleagues, patients and guests – all of whom occupied it. Together these come to form the Museum’s life: its past, present and future.29

As we know, in psychoanalysis, forgetting is vital to the formation of the human subject, whether this occurs through the function of the unconscious or our conscious capacity to forget. The Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna is problematic because it is all about remembering: it does not allow the visitor to forget.

The challenge that the Freud Museum Vienna presents us with is not that it is a ‘fake museum’ made up of ‘fake souvenirs’, but that it is all too real. In its seeming emptiness and absence, the mnemic images confront us with our own desires, by eliciting us to remember and insisting upon the impossibility of forgetting. As Phillips (1994: 34) reminds us about the interplay of forgetting and remembering,
Remembering, at any given moment, is a process of redescription; the echo can be different each time. The past is in the remaking. Remembering is a prospective project. But it is as though we are continually remaking something that to all intents and purposes never existed; or perhaps because we are making copies without an original – a representable original – all the copies are different?
Meaning is made, according to Freud, in the revision consequent upon deferral. The status, or the state, of what is forgotten is, in his account, indeterminate, so memory is a way of inventing the past. We are compulsive revisionists with an unknowable vision.

We bring to and fill the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna with our stories, memories, desires, fantasies, expectations, as well as our historical knowledge, our investments in psychoanalysis, our understanding of what a museum is, how we expect it to present itself to us and its various functions. This is the fullness that we bring to the seemingly empty conceptual museum. Upon encountering a conceptual museum, something that seems so empty without objects and collections, we are provoked by it to remember what we bring to it. In doing so, we are made to reinvent and remake the past – as well as the present and future – of the museum, and our own. Thus, the seeming emptiness and absence played out through the spaces and the screen-like images and display of the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna open up to the viewer to be filled again. In this conceptual museum there is no restitution on offer for our expectations, for our desires; with the past, and with our memories. And this lack of restitution encountering the fullness that we bring to it, makes the seeming emptiness and absence all too full; all too present.

I am introducing and using the term ‘site-responsive’ as a necessary means of understanding the unique blend of a particular site (with all of its historical, conceptual and imaginative certainties and contingencies) and the ‘responsivity’ of the contemporary art placed within it. In this instance, I am concerned with the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna and its relationship to contemporary art, specifically, through its Contemporary Art Collection. In defining site-responsivity, I refer to the ways in which these works are shown and (sometimes) housed in the Museum, but were not made ‘specifically’ for the Museum; instead the works are ‘responsive’ to the site in that they activate and animate in new ways the complex historical, theoretical and imaginative aspects of the Museum. In return, the Museum sheds new light on the artworks and interventions held therein. Thus I claim in my book Inside the Freud Museums: Art, Curating and Site-Responsivity, that site-responsive artworks, whether in Vienna or the Freud Museum London, or in other locations, activate a reciprocal dialogue between artworks, exhibitions and context.
For a detailed analysis of Freud’s last months in Vienna, see Cohen (2009).

H.D. (Hilda Doolittle, 1974[1956]: 3) writes in her memoir of her psychoanalysis with Freud:
The stone staircase was curved. There were two doors on the landing. The one to the right was the Professor’s professional door; the one to the left, the Freud family door. Apparently, the two apartments had been arranged so that there should be as little confusion as possible between family and patients or students; there was the Professor who belonged to us, there was the Professor who belonged to the family; it was a large family with ramifications, in-laws, distant relatives, family friends.
For the order and number of photographs that Engelman shot, see Werner (2002: 448, fn 3).

See also Werner (2002: 449), when he writes:
Engelman pointed out that the objects he saw numbered more than 2,000. They were often moved around by the housekeeper [Paula Fichtl] when she cleaned, but also were moved by Freud. Engelman recalls taking pictures of Freud’s desk and then returning to see statues in different locations.

Werner (2002: 447) quotes Engelman in an interview as saying, ‘I took pictures of the rooms according to how they were laid out. I then went back and took another tour of the rooms to get details missed out in the first effort.’

Fuss with Sanders (2004) offer us a spatial, architectural and psychoanalytic analysis of Freud’s work spaces in Berggasse 19, based on Engelman’s photographs and other documentation. For a personal account of Berggasse, see Bettelheim (1989a[1956]).

For a comparative analysis of the ethnographic and art museum, see Bal (1996); on the document, see Rehberg (2005); on the souvenir and its relationship to history and memory, see Steward (1993).

There is a long history of artists pointing to, and using the radically empty gallery as a means of denoting the constitution of the work of art and the gallery as an ideological, social, economic and cultural construction. See, for instance, Yves Klein’s The Specialization of Sensibility in the Raw Material State Into Stabilized Pictorial Sensibility (otherwise known as Le Vide/The Void) (Paris: Galerie Iris Clert, 1958); Art & Language’s The Air-Conditioning Show, 1966–1972 (Visual Arts Gallery, New York, 1972); Robert Barry’s Closed Gallery Piece, 1969–1970 (Amsterdam, Turin and Los Angeles, 1969–1970), and his Some places to which we can come, and for a while ‘be free to think about what we are going to do’ (Marcuse) (First presentation Galleria Sperone, Turin, 1970, 1970–in progress); Robert Irwin’s Experimental Situation (Ace Gallery, Los Angeles, 1970); Michael Asher’s October 7–October 10, 1974 (Anna Leonowens Gallery, Nova Scotia College of Art and Design, Halifax, Canada, 1974); Laurie Parsons’ Untitled (Lorence-Monk Gallery, New York, 1990); Bethan Huws’ Haus Esters Piece (Museum Haus Esters, Krefeld, 1993); Maria Eichhorn’s Money at the Kunsthalle Bern (Kunsthalle, Bern, 2001); Ilya and Emilia Kabakov’s ‘The Empty Museum’ (Sculpture Centre, New York, 2004); Roman Ondák’s More Silent Than Ever (gb agency, Paris, 2006). See also Armleder et al. (2009). The Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna has not taken the new media immersive approach that has been proposed for other empty museums, see for example, Hernández et al. (2004).

On the phenomenological, psychoanalytic, gendering and spatial impact of architectural interiors on the occupant, visitor and critic, see Colomina (1992, 2000). See also La Belle (2011) and Thibaud (forthcoming).
On the power/knowledge nexus that functions within all museums, and its impact on the spectator, see, for instance, Bennett (1996).

Of course there is a type of empty museum that is common: one that does not have a permanent collection or display, but prefers to show temporary exhibitions. These types of museums are different from the Sigmund Freud Museum Vienna and from the conceptual museum for which I am arguing in that the former always have an exhibition on display – albeit a temporary one – when visitors attend; whereas the latter seems to be open when empty, and that emptiness is its exhibition. For an analysis of the former in Japan, see Morishita (2010).

On the history of the Museum, its ideological, political and epistemological trajectories, see, for instance, Adorno (1967), Bennett (1995), Candlin (2001), Duncan (1995), Greenberg et al. (1995), Henning (2006), Hooper-Greenhill (1992), Macleod (2005), Message (2007), Pollock (2007b), Putnam (2001) and Rogoff and Sherman (1994).
Fiona Candlin, in conversation, has used the term ‘personality museum’ to describe a museum based on the life and work of a single individual.
I would like to thank Adrian Rifkin for this important distinction.

There are, of course, some similarities here between museums and memorials that also interrogate the notion of representability and are not a form of memorialization as positive reassurance. However, the memorial is a different type of monument to the museum, and my interest here is specifically on the museum, and the outlining of a notion of the conceptual museum.

Since 1976, Berggasse 19 has also housed the Sigmund Freud House Archive, the secretariat of the Sigmund Freud Society, and the Association of the Friends of Sigmund Freud Museum in the mezzanine level apartments. At that time, the Sigmund Freud House (including Museum, Library, Archive, Society and Association) at Berggasse 19 became the property of the City of Vienna, and in 2003 the Museum became part of the now private Sigmund Freud Foundation.

The classic text on the white cube is of course O’Doherty (1999). See also the important texts by Buren (1973a, 1973b, 1975).

See also Pollock (2007a) and Pollock (2006), particularly when she writes:
The terms prehistory, sedimented layers, and temporal strata evoke what has been frequently noted as the ‘archaeological metaphor’ that is deeply embedded in Freudian psychoanalysis. For Freud … memory was never … a recoverable world of sensation laced with emotion. It is already a mnemic trace that functions psychically … whose substance is marked only by a psychic representative – a coded displacement or translation. A memory image structures for the subject the remnant of unfinished emotional business that hinges the subject and human culture forever between an incomplete past and an ever fully experienced present. This suggests, therefore, that subjectivity can only be grasped chrono-topologically and in a profound relation between what is absent(ed) – the lost moment of formative sensation and emotion – and what is imaged/imagined as its trace in the psychic representational system generated in response to the initial welter of impressions and intensities. (pp. 5–6).
[And earlier in the text]

Now Vienna’s Freud Museum, the Berggasse 19’s empty shell houses only photographic replicas of the contents of a complex interior scheme of images, books and artifacts in which Freud’s passions and his professional and vacation journeys through art, archaeology, anthropology, and psychology were visually charted in a rebus of images. (p. 2)

[And then later]
The reference to archaeology [and we can include here the entire rebus of images that Pollock mentions above] demonstrates, I suggest, a profound engagement with both the function of the image in the structure of memory and the structure of mnemonic images in the formation of the subject. (p. 3)
On the relationship between memory and architectural space, see the classic texts: Bachelard (1969[1958]) and Lefebvre (1991).

bio.p: Joanne Morra is Reader in Art History and Theory at Central Saint Martins College of Art and Design, University of the Arts London. She has published widely on modern and contemporary art, has edited many collections, and is a Founder and Principal Editor of Journal of Visual Culture. She is presently writing a book on contemporary art and the Freud Museums (London and Vienna) entitled Inside the Freud Museums: Art, Curating and Site-Responsivity for IB Tauris.
